There's a new sense of urgency in cities on the East Coast after Hurricane Sandy.
Scientists can't predict when the next big storm will come, but they can say that a warmer climate is likely to make Atlantic storms bigger and increase flooding.
The Boston area is one urban center that's trying to prepare and NPR's Christopher Joyce went there to find out what they're doing.
From Kerry Emanuel's sixth floor office at MIT, you can look down at the snow-covered Charles River as it snakes through Boston down to the harbor.
It's a beautiful city where three rivers meet the Atlantic, except a lot of that water wants to get into the city and here's why.
First, the Atlantic is warming.
Emanuel says that puts more water vapor up into the air.
That means that a given hurricane is likely to rain much more in the future than it does today.
That's a big deal because a lot of the deaths and injuries and loss of property and so forth in these storms come from fresh water flooding produced by rain.
Then there's sea level.
Emanuel, an atmospheric scientist, says warming climate is likely to change wind patterns.
And those wind patterns can make a difference locally to how high the sea level it is.
So, for example, sea levels forecast arrives faster along the U.S.
East Coast than it does globally.
So you get flooding rivers and a surging ocean that meet in Boston Harbor.
This is something that we're worried about.

Boston has several waterfront neighborhoods like this and buildings dating back centuries.
